body:
> Another approach to solve this is to explicitly enforce partition based replica group for upsert tables and make sure that each (replica group, partition) has 1 server.
> 
> ```
> 6 servers, 6 partition, 2 replication
> 
> (rg_id, partition_id) -> [list of servers]
> 0, 0 -> server_0
> 0, 1 -> server_1
> 0, 2 -> server_2
> 0, 3 -> server_0
> 0, 4 -> server_1
> 0, 5 -> server_2
> 1, 0 -> server_3
> 1, 1 -> server_4
> 1, 2 -> server_5
> 1, 3 -> server_3
> 1, 4 -> server_4
> 1, 5- > server_5
> ```
> 
> This will provide the explicit guarantee for upsert property + protection from the rebalance. Also, we can keep the strict replica group logic as is. but, if we go with this route, we will need to go back to all the existing upsert tables and reconfigure the replica group setup.

@snleee That is already here. The trigger for this issue is the instance partitions was updated, but rebalance was aborted without updating the IS. Essentially IS goes in-sync with the instance partitions. We want to gracefully handle it when adding a new segment to the IS

Thanks for reporting the issue. Would you like to help contribute a fix for this?
Created a related issue in terms of the PinotFS interface description. https://github.com/apache/pinot/issues/11491

@Jackie-Jiang : We saw that `PinotFS::lastModified` says that it is okay to return 0 in case of errors, but I think that could lead to major bugs in the future because usually people use lastModified to dictate decisions related to data deletion.

In other words, returning 0 in case of errors would pass validations such as:

```
System.currentTimeMillis() > pinotFS.lastModified(uri)
```

which could lead to unintended deletions.

At present this API is only called in `SegmentDeletionManager` for deletion of data under `Deleted_Segments` dir so we have been fine for now, but it could easily cause a incident from a future code-change.

If changing the contract of this API is not possible, can we consider deprecating this and introducing a new API with proper semantics?

> @Jackie-Jiang So, our new approach should be:
> 
> * Block IS update if it violates the instance mapping. Emit metrics + setup alert for observability.
> 
> Is my understanding correct? It sounds good to me.

We want to assign new segment based on the existing segment assignment in IS to avoid violating the mapping, but also emit metric when we detect IS and instance partitions are in-sync
@Jackie-Jiang @mayankshriv

@kishoreg Currently we use IS only to determine the segment group (segments that should be routed together). The actual segment state is read from the EV, and we can handle OFFLINE/ERROR etc correctly. What we can potentially improve on the routing side is to read actual ZK metadata to determine the segment group, and after that it should remain the same.

Essentially, the routing side change:
- Is not a must have if we keep IS consistent (all segments of the same partition are assigned to the same set of servers)
- If IS is inconsistent, this won't be able to fix the query issue, but can return exception instead of potential wrong result

Instead, the assignment side change is a must have, so I'd suggest not do routing side change as of now

> We want to assign new segment based on the existing segment assignment in IS to avoid violating the mapping, but also emit metric when we detect IS and instance partitions are in-sync

This will work for the consuming segments but how should we deal with the table rebalance with 'reassign segments' on e.g. during cluster scale ups. 

In that case there's no existing segment assignment 

Secondly, what should be the deciding criteria if there is conflict in the IS already before we assign the consuming segment?

> Does it work if user explicitly select virtual column?

Yes. This method is only called when adding columns in `select *`. The main issue is that is not explicitly said in Calcite's javadoc. I've added a comment including the discussion in Calcite dev email list when Julian Hyde says this is not a supported feature and invite us to add a proposal (something we should do, but I guess we want to solve the issue first).

I've added a couple of test to verify the behavior and detect a possible regression in future.
I remember discussing this for Tableau as well. The reason it wasn't done is cause it breaks backward compatibility for people already using this function.

Hi, thank you very much for this quick fix.
I would suggest to add `WWW-Authenticate: Basic` in the response header in case of 401 to be fully complaint with Http 1.1
Maybe adding an ExceptionMapper like the one on pinot-controller would help...?

https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/master/pinot-controller/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/controller/api/resources/WebApplicationExceptionMapper.java

> Maybe we should always use BigDecimal to perform the comparison and set value for floating-point numbers

No please. That would destroy the performance. I don't think we can merge this without doing proper benchmarking

TBH I think we are treating this as an issue when it actually isn't. It is normal on databases to use IEEE 754 and just advice about that. For example:
- https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/datatype-numeric.html#DATATYPE-FLOAT
- https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/problems-with-float.html
- https://www.crunchydata.com/blog/choosing-a-postgresql-number-format
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/916081/convert-float-to-double-without-losing-precision (this explains why it feels better to transform to string first, but we could do the same without creating the String. See the 3rd point below)

In my opinion we should:
1. Support DECIMAL type (in case we don't already do it) for cases where precision is more important than performance
2. Document that floats and doubles are in fact floating point numbers and therefore their precision is not guaranteed
3. Offer some casting operation that can be customized (something like: cast this float to double rounding to the 3rd decimal)
4. Always use doubles in real number literals when parsing queries
   - ideally we should use floats when we know the expression types to a float, but we may not know that given that the literals will be obtained by the lexer, which executes before the typing

> Hi, thank you very much for this quick fix. I would suggest to add `WWW-Authenticate: Basic` in the response header in case of 401 to be fully complaint with Http 1.1 Maybe adding an ExceptionMapper like the one on pinot-controller would help...?
> 
> https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/master/pinot-controller/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/controller/api/resources/WebApplicationExceptionMapper.java

Thanks for the suggestion. I think we don't need the ExceptionMapper, just instead of throwing the [javax.ws.rs.WebApplicationException](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/ws/rs/WebApplicationException.html); we should throw the [javax.ws.rs.NotAuthorizedException](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/ws/rs/NotAuthorizedException.html). The `challenge` will be set as `WWW-Authenticate: <challenge>` in response header.

However, my worry is hardcoding the value to `Basic`. @Jackie-Jiang is it okay to hardcode the value to `Basic`?

@xiangfu0 sorry, I cleared up the description. The stack trace happens on servers, but we can set that aside for a second; the minions are not *attempting* to build the native indices at all, which is the bug here. 

But, to answer your question, we did a bunch of experiments with different memory settings on our servers and things consistently failed for some set of segments; I think https://github.com/apache/pinot/issues/10934 will help with that. But, regardless, we _need_ **minions** to build the native indices, and **not** servers.

In case it's helpful, @mneedham pointed me to https://github.com/apache/pinot/blob/master/pinot-segment-local/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/segment/local/segment/index/loader/invertedindex/TextIndexHandler.java#L121, which seems to not handle this case.
